_desc.NAICS_DESCRIPTION: Other Chemical and Allied Products Merchant Wholesalers

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

In this chemical and other allied wholesale facility, we handle chlorine which is considered hazardous by EPA.  The same properties that makes chlorine valuable as a retail/wholesale chemical, also makes it necessary to observe certain safety precautions while handling. Overall, the prevention of unnecessary human exposure, reducing the treat to our own personal health as well as our co-worker, and reducing the threat to nearby members of the community is the main goal of incorporating this risk management plan into our daily operations.  It is our policy to adhere to all applicable federal and state rules and regulations. Safety depends upon the manner in which we handle chlorine combined with the safety storage devices inherent in the design of this facility, with the safe handling procedures that we utilize, and the training of our personnel.

Our emergency response (action) program was developed with the assistance of Environmental Services Group, Inc.  The emergency response plan includes procedures for notification of trained HazMat Personnel from the Little Rock Fire Department to respond to a release of chlorine.  This facility has no employees who are trained to respond.  If Hazmat response is required, the Little Rock Fire Department to respond to a release of chlorine.  This facility has no employees who are trained to respond.  If Hazmat response is required, the Little Rock Fire department will be contacted.  Fabriclean Supply of Arkansas (FSA) will then notify 911 for notification to Pulaski County LEPC and other agencies.

The primary purpose of this facility is to receive and distribute pre-packaged chlorine to customers. Chlorine is received in 150 pound cylinders at the 6600 Allied Way location and stored in the warehouse until sold and distributed.  The chlorine is stored in the warehouse area in designated areas.  The area is a well ventilated concrete floor.  Maximum quantity on hand will not exceed 30,000 pounds.  Access to t

he site is restricted to authorized facility employees, authorized management personnel, and authorized management personnel, and authorized contractors.

The regulated substance stored at the 6600 Allied Way location is chlorine.  The maximum amount of chlorine that can be stored in the warehouse if 30,000 pounds.

The worst-case scenario is failure of my largest storage tank when filled to the greatest amount allowed would release 150 pounds of chlorine from the 6600 Allied Way location. Passive mitigation has been considered for this scenario.  The chlorine cylinders are located in the warehouse building which is constructed of a concrete floor and concrete walls. . The receiving dock and bay door is open to the air when the door is open to the air when the door is open.  It is assumed that the entire content of the 150 lb. cylinder is released as a toxic vapor. The distance to the endpoint of 0.0087 mg/l for the worst-case scenario is 0.4 miles.  This location is classified as urban due to the dense concentration of buildings and people.

An alternative scenario was determined for this facility; however based on the type of prevention system in place and the no-use chlorine, the potential for an alternative release from a 150 lb. cylinder should be minimal for the 6600 Allied Way site.  Since chlorine is not actually used in a process, rather it is only stored, there should not be a release from a chlorine cylinder.  All cylinders are repackaged and inspected by the supplier prior to arrival at FSA.  The alternative release scenario from a 150 lb. cylinder for the 6600 Allied Way site would possibly occur because of an improperly sealed packaging nut at the valve.   An estimation of the release would be approximately 5 pounds of toxic vapor being released into the atmosphere.  The amount of toxic valve released from the chlorine leak would result in an estimated distance to toxic endpoint of approximately 0.1 miles.

This chemical distributing facility complies

with EPA's Accidental Release Prevention Rule and with all applicable state codes and regulations.

We have had no accidental releases of chlorine in the last five years.  The chlorine is received, stored, and loaded with trained personnel, and the likelihood of a release of chlorine from the cylinders is minimal.

Our emergency response (action) program was developed with the assistance of Environmental Service Group, Inc..  We have discussed this program with the Pulaski County LEPC and the Little Rock Fire Department. A representative of Environmental Service Group, Inc. visited this plant April 27, 2010, which prompted a review of safety programs at this facility.
